data.title: Morning Buzz
data.text:
ESPN has agreed to a deal that locks down MLB rights into the next decade, according to several sources. The eight-year deal is worth $5.6B (an average of $700M per year), approximately doubling the nearly $306M ESPN currently pays MLB every year for domestic TV rights. The new deal adds in digital, international and radio, for which ESPN is paying MLB around $50M currently, sources said. Sources added the deal will be announced as soon as this afternoon. As part of the deal, which runs through ‘21, ESPN retains the rights to "Sunday Night Baseball," its Monday and Wednesday night games and highlights for "Baseball Tonight."

ESPN also will carry one Wild Card playoff game, sources said. In its current deal, ESPN does not have rights to any MLB playoffs. As part of the deal, ESPN adds more digital rights, the rights to show games in-progress and some radio and international rights. ESPN also picked up rights to carry games featuring more popular teams, like the Yankees and Red Sox, more frequently.

For more, see today's issue of THE DAILY.

Penguins C Evgeni Malkin "has agreed to a contract to play" for KHL club Metallurg Magnitogorsk "if the start of the 2012-13 NHL season is delayed by a lockout," according to reports in Russia. Malkin's agent, J.P. Barry, confirmed that his client "has spoken with teams in Moscow and Magnitogorsk about a week-to-week agreement that would allow him to play during a lockout, if there is one, but that nothing has been finalized" (PITTSBURGH POST-GAZETTE, 8/28). Lightning RW Martin St. Louis said that he "will play in Europe this season if the NHL locks out its players for an extended period" (TAMPA BAY TIMES, 8/28).

CBA talks resume today at NHL HQs in N.Y., and many players "expect the league to submit another plan" today. Penguins RW and NHLPA rep Craig Adams said that "many peripheral issues have been resolved" (PITSBURGH TRIBUNE-REVIEW, 8/28). There will be "only four men at the table" for today's talks: NHL Commissioner Gary Bettman, Deputy Commissioner Bill Daly, NHLPA Exec Dir Donald Fehr and NHLPA outside counsel Steve Fehr. Donald Fehr said, "Hopefully we'll be productive when we get to it. ... I have always believed that there is enough time" (SPORTINGNEWS.com, 8/27).

The Virginia Beach City Council today will "hear a proposal to build an 18,000-seat arena near the Virginia Beach Convention Center." City officials said that Comcast-Spectacor "has guaranteed that if it is built, a professional sports team will come to Virginia Beach." The NBA Kings have been rumored to be the the target tenants (Norfolk VIRGINIAN-PILOT, 8/28). Virginia Beach Mayor Bill Sessoms said, "I would look for help from the Commonwealth, from special tax districts at the oceanfront, perhaps an increase on the tax on hotel rooms and ticket sale revenues" (WAVY.com, 8/28).

G4S, the security firm for the London Games, today said that its "loss on the bungled contract will be in the region" of US$80M. G4S is "conducting an internal review after its failure to provide" all of the 10,400 contracted guards forced the U.K. government to "step in with military personnel." The firm said that it had delivered 83% of contracted shifts and that it was "confident the imminent Paralympic Games would be fully staffed with a security workforce" (PA, 8/28).

As Tropical Storm Isaac nears hurricane strength and threatens the Gulf Coast, several sports teams are adjusting their travel and playing schedules. Officials from Louisiana Tech "hope to decide by this afternoon" whether the football season opener Thursday night against Texas A&M will take place in Shreveport's Independence Stadium. Shreveport is "roughly 200 miles inland," but it "could be used for evacuees from the coast." The game is slated to be broadcast on ESPNU (SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS-NEWS, 8/28).

The Saints opted to fly to Cincinnati last night ahead of Thursday's preseason game against the Titans. The team was "slated to depart for Nashville on Wednesday, but Isaac forced officials to push up plans and hastily call the players in for an emergency hurricane meeting Sunday" (New Orleans TIMES-PICAYUNE, 8/28).

The Univ. of New Orleans is evacuating 40 of its athletes to Millsaps College in Jackson, Miss. UNO men's basketball coach Mark Slessinger said that "his entire team was included in the contingent" (NOLA.com, 8/27).

Marlins Park "endured its first brush with tropical weather without damage with the retractable roof being secured in hurricane mode." Winds from Isaac gusted at 30-40mph as the storm passed over South Florida on Sunday. Marlins Exec VP/Ballpark Development Claude Delorme said that the venue "will be ready to open a nine-game homestand" tonight against the Nationals (South Florida SUN-SENTINEL, 8/28).

Sources said that NASCAR driver Martin Truex Jr. has agreed to an extension to continue driving the Sprint Cup Series No. 56 Toyota for Michael Waltrip Racing "with NAPA as his primary sponsor." A formal announcement is scheduled for Friday at Atlanta Motor Speedway (ESPN.com, 8/27).

The Glendale City Council yesterday directed staff to extend its arena management deal with the NHL "for another 30 days," giving Greg Jamison "more time to try to buy" the league-owned Coyotes (ARIZONA REPUBLIC, 8/28).

The Ram Truck brand has signed on as the presenting sponsor of the college football studio show on the ACC Network. "ACC Blitz presented by Ram Trucks" will debut Sept. 1 (Raycom Sports).

EA Sports runs a full-page color ad in USA Today promoting the release of "Madden NFL 13," featuring Lions WR Calvin Johnson (THE DAILY).

Barclay runs a full-page color ad in the N.Y. Times and Wall Street Journal congratulating golfer Nick Watney for winning The Barclays, the first event in this year's PGA Tour Playoffs for the FedEx Cup (THE DAILY).

“To be honest, Football Championship Subdivision is a mouthful, and it doesn't make the case for our Division I stature really much better than the I-AA moniker did. We've tried to fix this for years. It's a dilemma” – Missouri Valley Conference Commissioner Patty Viverito, on the name of college football's second tier (AP, 8/27).

"It's a little sad to me that it's hard to get a ticket to see, say, an Alabama play if you don't have, quote, 'points' where you have given something to the university or some foundation or something and build your way up" – Former Univ. of Alabama football coach Gene Stallings on the business of college football (Al.com, 8/27).

"Because of the pain I was having. It was really weird. They told me I was fine, not pregnant. I'm like, 'Can I get my money back?'" – Tennis player Maria Sharapova on having tests done for a stomach virus after the London Games (L.A. TIMES, 8/28).

AP's Rob Harris: "Transport for London boss Peter Hendy says no one has fainted on the Tube for 3 weeks. … Paralympics is on course to be a 2.5 million ticket sellout."

CP’s Chris Johnston: "New York-bound for CBA talks. What's the over/under on the length of today's meeting?"

Globe & Mail's Bruce Dowbiggin: "Only thing sadder than Quebec Anglos hoping for respect and rights are those who keep pimping Lance Armstrong after even he knows it's over."

Padres President & COO Tom Garfinkel: "Great idea from a fan at social media night - chargers for electric cars in parking lot. Working on it."

If you see a tweet we will not want to miss, send it to us at editorial@sportsbusinessdaily.com.

CBS’ David Letterman: “How about that Lance Armstrong, were you surprised by that? He said, ‘Look, I can’t take it anymore. I’m tired of this nonsense. You folks do whatever you want. Leave me out of this. I don’t have a dog in this fight any more.’ So, the World Governing Bicycle Association stripped him of all of his titles. Also, you know what else this means, that he will have no chance now of being Kelly Ripa’s co-host. … Before we all start piling on Lance Armstrong, let me remind you of one very important factor: he was the first person to walk on the moon. … Lance Armstrong said, ‘Dave, I want to be on your show to say goodnight to everybody and thank everybody for all their support. Ladies and gentlemen, here he is, Lance Armstrong.” An overweight "Late Show" staffer came out on a bicycle, dressed in Armstrong’s yellow jersey and bicycle shorts, and circled around Letterman on the stage. Letterman: “Wow. That yellow is not very slimming, is it? … Roger Clemens over the weekend returned to professional baseball. He pitched down there in Houston for a minor-league team, the Houston Geezers, I think. ... He’s 50 years old, making a comeback in Major League Baseball. I’m told that he’s here tonight. Ladies and gentlemen, Roger Clemens.” The same Late Show staffer came out again on a bicycle, this time wearing a Yankees cap and jersey. Letterman: “I think the pinstripes are better than the yellow” (“Late Show,” CBS, 8/27).

Last night’s Top Ten list was “Top Ten Fresco Restorer Excuses.” Letterman: “An elderly woman, a parishioner, attempted to restore a 19th Century fresco depicting Jesus Christ wearing a crown of thorns. … It was an original fresco by Elias Garcia Martinez in Borja, Spain” (“Late Show,” CBS, 8/27).

10) “Should have used a Sharpie.”

9) “It was supposed to look like who?”

8) “Hey, don’t worry, that’s just the primer.”

7) “Still looks better than Christ’s driver license photo.”

6) “I was counting on a miracle.”

5) “If you squint … nope, still looks like a monkey.”

4) “At least I wasn’t skinny-dipping in the Sea of Galilee.”

3) “Uh … hiccups?”

2) “You’ve been ‘fresco’d!’”

1) “It can’t be that bad – everyone who sees it says, ‘Jesus Christ!’”
